Title: Just a Trim
Content: Cʜᴀʀᴀᴄᴛᴇʀs
LONNIE: 13-year-old girl
ASIA: 13-year-old girl
JEREMIAH: Asia's brother, 11 years old
[The curtain rises. Asia and Lonnie are sitting on a couch in Asia's living room reading magazines.]
LONNIE: Would this haircut look good on me? [She turns the magazine around so that the page is facing Asia.]
ASIA: [Squeals.] Yes! I love the asymmetrical cut for the summer.
LONNIE: It's so cool. Raquel Johnson totally rocked this look at the music awards show last week. Have you heard her new song?
ASIA: Of course! [Singing.] “Sometimes you have to find a perfect — ”
[Jeremiah enters quickly.]
JEREMIAH: [Faking panic.] Is everything okay? It sounded like someone was hurt!
ASIA: Very funny. Go away.
JEREMIAH: Trust me. I do not want to be here. I'm just getting my baseball cap. [He walks to the other side of the room, retrieves his cap, and exits.]
LONNIE: This style has to be cut flawlessly.
ASIA: It can't be that hard to copy. There's some layering around your face, but it looks easy enough.
LONNIE: I'll call the salon around the corner.
ASIA: You should let me do it. Right now.
LONNIE: Do you even know how to cut hair?
ASIA: Yes. My family never goes to the salon. My dad cuts our hair. I've watched him do it a thousand times. The scissors and apron are upstairs.
LONNIE: [Raising her eyebrows.] So you've never actually cut anyone's hair before?
ASIA: Don't worry. Anyway, why should you pay a salon when I'll do it for free?
LONNIE: [Pauses.] Fine. But start by just trimming my hair. Then we'll see.
ASIA: I'll get the scissors.
[Asia runs offstage. Lonnie sits in a chair, tapping her foot and flipping through a magazine. Asia enters and puts an apron on Lonnie.]
ASIA: This shouldn't take long.

[Lonnie closes her eyes tightly. Asia holds a thick bunch of Lonnie's hair and puts it between the blades of the scissors. She closes her eyes and cuts. When she opens her eyes, she lets out a deep breath.]
LONNIE: [Opening one eye.] Is everything okay?
ASIA: Of course!
[Asia smiles widely as she continues cutting. She sings and snips with g͟u͟s͟t͟o. Lonnie sits quietly. After a few minutes, Asia stops singing and stares at Lonnie's hair. Jeremiah enters.]
JEREMIAH: Asia, have you seen my baseball ba — What are you doing?
ASIA: I'm giving Lonnie a makeover.
JEREMIAH: Into what?
[Lonnie sits up straight and stares at Jeremiah.]
ASIA: Go away, Jeremiah. [To Lonnie.] Don't worry. Everything's fine.
JEREMIAH: Sure, if you want to look like a wild dog. [He exits.]
LONNIE: Can I have a mirror?

ASIA: Not yet. [She stops cutting and holds the magazine next to Lonnie's face. She looks at the magazine and then at Lonnie. She speaks slowly.] How would you feel about parting your hair on the left instead of the right?
LONNIE: [Anxiously.] What? Why? In the magazine the girl's hair was parted in the middle.
ASIA: Relax! [She continues cutting Lonnie's hair.] I'm just adding some ... flair.
LONNIE: Give me a mirror!
ASIA: You have to wait until I'm done. [She continues cutting.]
LONNIE: Asia! Stop. I want to see my hair.
ASIA: No problem. I just finished. It's exactly what I was going for.
[Lonnie stands and walks over to the mirror hanging on the wall. She shrieks.]
LONNIE: Oh, no! I can't let anyone see me like this!

ASIA: Why not? It's cut short on one side and long on the other. It's just like in the magazine. Well, maybe a little different, but that's a good thing, right? You don't want to copy someone's look anyway, do you? You're a trendsetter!
LONNIE: There is nothing attractive about this. [She holds up a mangled cluster of hair in front of her watering eyes.]
ASIA: [Frowning.] You don't like it?
LONNIE: If you think it looks so great, then put on this apron and I'll give you this haircut.
ASIA: Well ... umm ... we have different facial structures. You look nice with shorter hair. My face is round. Long hair suits me better.
LONNIE: Just admit that you messed up. This haircut is terrible!
[Asia stares at the ground and says nothing. There is a moment of quiet. Jeremiah enters.]

JEREMIAH: Are you sure my bat isn't in —  [He stops and stares at Lonnie's hair. He walks to Lonnie and takes off his baseball cap.] I think you're going to need this. [He puts the hat on her head and exits.]
LONNIE: What am I going to do? You ruined my hair!
ASIA: Look, I'm sorry. [Pauses.] I'll call the salon and set up an appointment for both of us. I'll get the same haircut as you. We'll be all anyone can talk about.
LONNIE: In a good way, I hope. And the next time you get one of your wild ideas, you get to go first.
ASIA: [Smiling.] That's fair. I'm sure that way I'll give it a little more thought.
[Asia and Lonnie begin sweeping up the hair clippings. Curtain closes.]
